title: Michael van Gerwen claims Champions League of Darts belt in stunning win over Peter Wright
text:
Michael van Gerwen claimed his first Champions League title on Sunday (Picture: Getty)

Michael van Gerwen won the Champions League of Darts for the first time on Sunday night with a spectacular 11-10 victory over Peter Wright.

The Champions League was the only major televised tournament that Van Gerwen had not won and he has now completed the set with the thrilling win.

It looked to be another year of disappointment in the event for the Dutchman, though, with Snakebite leading 10-7 and having three clear darts at double 12 to win the title, but firing wide of the target.

Mighty Mike reeled off the final four legs of the match to hand Wright yet another heartbreaking defeat in a final, and claim the unique new belt and £100,000.

Wright has just one major title to his name, the 2017 UK Open, but has finished runner-up at the World Championship, Matchplay, Grand Prix, Grand Slam, Premier League and now twice in the Champions League.

This is what it was all about. The Champions League of Darts belt. pic.twitter.com/hd4IszPIpE — Paddy Power (@paddypower) October 20, 2019

The victory for the Dutchman is his eighth over the Scot in major finals and MVG is delighted to maintain his hoodoo over the world number seven.

‘He’s a phenomenal player, we all know that,’ Van Gerwen said of his beaten opponent. ‘We’re going to have a lot more finals, there can only be one winner and I’m really glad it’s me.’

MICHAEL VAN GERWEN IS THE CHAMPION! From the brink of defeat, MVG completes his clean sweep of PDC titles and becomes the 2019 @paddypower Champions League of Darts Champion! pic.twitter.com/cGf4dyImzs — PDC Darts (@OfficialPDC) October 20, 2019

Wright will rue his missed opportunities after he had played fantastically well to give himself the golden opportunity to win the match.

Snakebite led 6-3, 8-5 and then looked in total command at 10-7, but the three misses at double 12 will keep him up late into the night.

‘When Peter had those three darts clear at double 12 I thought it was over,’ Van Gerwen admitted. ‘But before the last dart he turned around and looked really nervous and I thought this may be a moment for me to step in and I’m really glad I could.’

Good night everyone 🏆😴 pic.twitter.com/VRY8tRRoSM — Michael Van Gerwen (@MvG180) October 20, 2019

MVG ended the match with a thoroughly impressive average of 100.87, with Wright slipping down to 97.42 by the end of the game as nerves got the better of him.

The 49-year-old will have to settle for the substantial runners-up prize of £50,000.
